Why is good the best possible performance important?

  • Usability, Accessibility
  • Slow WiFi
  • GPRS/Edge/3G connections (e.g. in subways)
  • Roaming
  • Conversion rates
  • Limited dataplans

Websites keep getting fatter and fatter


http://www.sitepoint.com/average-page-weight-increases-15-2014

How can you measure performance?

DevTools

https://developer.chrome.com/devtools/docs/timeline

Google PageSpeed Insights

https://developers.google.com/speed/pagespeed/insights/

WebPagetest.org

http://www.webpagetest.org/

How can you measure performance?

  • DevTools
  • Google PageSpeed Insights
  • WebPagetest
  • yslow

What is good performance?

Source: http://offclouds.com/303577-speedy-gonzales.html

14kb

delivering the critical-path view (above the fold) in the first 14kb of the page

Pageload < 1 second

1.0 second is how long you have for the user’s state of flow to remain uninterrupted

SpeedIndex under 1000

Smooth Animation/Scrolling

Each frame completes in less than 16 milliseconds.

Performance Budget

A performance budget is just what it sounds like: you set a “budget” on your page and do not allow the page to exceed that.

Tim Kadlec

Performance Budget metrics

  1. Milestone timings

    eg. Load time, domContentLoaded, Time to render

  2. SpeedIndex

  3. Quantity based metrics

    eg. Total number of requests, Overall page weight, Total image weight

  4. Rule based metrics

    eg. PageSpeed score, YSlow score

Comparison with competitors

What do you do when you’re not within the budget?

  1. Optimize an existing feature or asset on the page.
  2. Remove an existing feature or asset from the page.
  3. Don’t add the new feature or asset.

Image optimization

1. Image file size

Desktop and Mobile each with 3987,857 kb (~4MB) images

Optimization Step 1

Lossy and lossless image compression

For example: ImageAlpha (lossy) and ImageOptim (lossless)

Optimization Step 1

File Compression

File sizes: 3987,857 KB (~4MB) -> 2027,063 KB (~2MB)

2. Image size

Desktop and Mobile each with 2027,063 KB (~2MB) images

Optimization Step 2

Save images in correct size

Images size: 2027,063 KB (~2MB) -> 1,168,480 KB (1.2MB)

PSI Score Step2

->

3. Responsive image

Desktop and Mobile each with 1,168,480 (1.2MB) images

Optimization Step 3

srcset

<img src="small.jpg"
 srcset="large.jpg 1024w, medium.jpg 640w, small.jpg 320w"
 alt="A rad wolf">

Optimization Step 3

Responsive images

Images size Mobile: 1,094,313 KB (~1.1MB) -> ~300 KB Images size Desktop: 1,168,480 KB (~1.2MB)

PSI Score Step3

->

4. Smaller Imageformats

Images size Mobile: ~300 KB
Images size Desktop: 1,168,480 KB (~1.2MB)

Optimization Step 4

WebP

  • Imageformat made by Google
  • Current only supported on Chrome, Opera, Android Webkit, Chrome Android
  • Sometimes bigger then original file

Optimization Step 4

Webp & picture

<picture> 
    <source type="image/webp" srcset="images/320/webp/bild3.webp 320w,  images/768/webp/bild3.webp 768w">
    <img src="images/320/bild3.jpg" srcset="images/768/bild3.jpg 768w" alt="">
</picture>

Optimization Step 4

Webp

Images size Mobile: ~300KB -> ~176 KB Images size Desktop: 1,168,480 KB (~1.2MB) -> ~528 KB

Speedindex Step4

Desktop: 2448 -> 2112
Mobile: 14632 -> 8675

CSS Optimization

1. Combine CSS Files

4 requests to CSS files

Optimization Step 5

Combine CSS files

grunt-concat-css, gulp-concat-css, gulp-usemin,…

2. Remove unused CSS

15KB Custom CSS
26KB Bootstrap theme
147KB Bootstrap
3KB Validation plugin

Total: 191KB CSS

Check pages for unused CSS

Chrome Dev Tools -> Audits -> Run

Optimization Step 6

Remove unused CSS

UnCss is a tool that removes unused CSS from your stylesheets. It works across multiple files and supports Javascript-injected CSS.

Optimization Step 6

Remove unused CSS

CSS 192KB -> 29KB

3. Minify CSS

29KB CSS file

Minify CSS

cssminifier, gulp-minify-css, grunt-contrib-cssmin,…

Optimization Step 7

Minify CSS

CSS 29KB -> 21KB
